The development of CO2 hydrogenation catalysts for hydrocarbon production is a challenging and relevant task as it can contribute to solving of the CO2 emission problem. In the present work, we describe our journey in the development of catalysts for operating in a slurry reactor. The screening of the preparation methods and catalyst composition yielded an active and highly selective CO2 hydrogenation catalyst with catalytic performances comparable to the best ones reported in the literature. The most perspective catalysts were successfully evaluated in CO2 hydrogenation using a slurry reactor. The supported catalysts were found to have a lower ability to form higher hydrocarbons compared to bulk catalysts. This could be correlated with the particle sizes of the active component of the respective catalysts. This insight may be useful in preparing tailor-made Fe-based catalysts with high chain growth probability. The important issue of mechanical strength for slurry operation was highlighted. Graphical Abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Catalyst development Slurry reactor Mechanical strength Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nowadays, around 80% of global energy is based on the combustion of fossil fuels including crude oil, natural gas, and coal [1]. This consumption of resources leads to an unavoidable increase in the concentration of carbon dioxide in our atmosphere, which is known to be one of the causes of the increased greenhouse effect leading to global warming [2]. The usage of CO2 as a feedstock to produce valuable organic compounds via hydrogenation could be considered as a potential solution for reducing CO2 emissions [3–5]. One such prospective, clean, and sustainable energy technology could be the direct CO2 hydrogenation to higher hydrocarbons, also known as CO2-Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (CO2-FTS) [5–8]. CO2-FTS is an attractive way for directly producing olefins, paraffins and potentially alcohols from carbon dioxide. It is generally accepted that the process of CO2-FTS proceeds in two stages: the reverse water gas shift reaction (CO2 + H2 ⇄ CO + H2O, RWGS, ∆ r H 523 K ° = 38 kJ·mol−1) followed by CO hydrogenation via FT reaction (CO + 2 H2 ⇄ -CH2- + H2O, CO-FT, ∆ r H 523 K ° = −166 kJ·mol−1) [9]. Fe-based catalyst are typically used for this process because they can catalyze both reactions. It was discussed that two Fe phases might be involved in this catalytic reaction. Iron oxide is responsible for catalyzing the first RWGS stage whereas iron carbide is an active phase of the CO-FT reaction [10–12]. However, it was also found [13] that some iron carbides are also able to directly hydrogenate CO2 to higher hydrocarbons (CO2 + 3 H2 ⇄ -CH2- + 2 H2O, CO2-FT, ∆ r H 523 K ° = −128 kJ·mol−1). It is well known that unpromoted Fe-based catalysts produce methane as undesired side-product in high selectivity [14]. Accordingly, great efforts have been spent to increase catalyst selectivity to desired products by doping the catalysts with different promoters [15–22]. As proven by systematic data analysis [23,24], the most popular and effective promoters are alkaline metals (K, Na) [16,25,26]. Doping with alkaline metals suppresses the undesired methane formation and increases the selectivity to higher hydrocarbons. This effect can be explained by the resulting increased binding strength of adsorbed CO2 and CO which leads to a reduction in hydrogenation activity as proven by in situ XPS and DFT calculation in [25] and underpinned by a DFT study [26]. Moreover, alkali metals are able to accelerate the formation of Fe5C2 [27,28] which is active in the FT reaction [11]. Since CO2-FTS is an exothermic process that yields a wide range of hydrocarbons (from light olefins to waxes), there are additional constraints in scaling up of the overall process. Fixed bed reactors are typically used for investigating CO2-FT catalysts. However, because of wax formation during FTS, pressure drop may increase, and diffusion and heat transfer limitations can occur [29] while catalyst removal during operation is impossible. From the technological point of view, an effective way to perform the process of the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis is to use fluidized bed or three-phase slurry reactors especially in industrial plants [30]. Performing the process in such a type of reactor has several advantages, including effective exchange of heat generated from the exothermic reaction, effective contact of reagents with a catalyst due to accelerating mass transfer, and possibility of continuous removal of spent or addition of fresh catalyst [31,32]. When employing Fe-based catalysts necessary for CO2-FTS, addition of fresh catalyst is crucial because of decreased catalyst lifetime when compared to Co. Finally, a fluidized bed reactor is only suitable for shorter chain hydrocarbons, commonly produced by high-temperature FTS at above 300 °C [33]. Longer hydrocarbons which are the focus of the presented study and catalyst development, would condensate on the catalyst and lead to agglomeration and ultimately fluidized bed slumping. Hence, only the slurry reactor offers the advantages of the fluidized bed while being able to operate in a continuous mode in the presence of waxes, making it the suitable choice for CO2 hydrogenation to higher hydrocarbons [17,34]. However, the operation in fluidized bed or slurry reactors places additional demands on the catalysts including high stability against attrition, a certain fluid dynamic density and a particle size for sufficient fluidization, etc. The development of CO2-FT catalysts that exhibit high activity, selectivity, and stability and meet the requirements for operation in slurry/fluidized bed reactors is a challenging task. In the present work, we present the first part of our journey in the development of CO2-FT catalysts that satisfy the requirements of three-phase slurry reactor. The first part is focused on the screening of highly active and selective catalysts which are chemically stable for operation. The strategy of the catalyst development is based on the results of a data analysis on CO2 hydrogenation catalysts for hydrocarbon production [23]. We have screened the manufacturing processes and catalyst composition in order to develop the most active and selective catalyst that fulfils the necessary requirements. A high-throughput catalytic setup with parallel fixed bed reactors was used for testing the obtained catalysts under CO2-FT condition. We also investigated physicochemical properties of the obtained catalysts to find correlation between catalyst activity/selectivity and properties. Finally, we performed catalytic tests of selected catalysts in a three-phase slurry reactor and investigated their mechanical stability. 2 Methodology 2.1 Requirements to CO 2 -FT catalysts CO2-FT catalysts have to fulfill a number of requirements including high catalytic activity and selectivity to hydrocarbons. A special interest to olefins is caused by the fact that light olefins C2-C4 are fundamental blocks of chemical industry [35] as well as C5+ olefins are versatile feedstocks and could be used as value-added compounds for high-octane gasoline, synthetic lubricants, new polymers etc. [36,37] Thus, there is a need to suppress the formation of undesired products such as methane and carbon monoxide. CO is an intermediate compound and could be recycled after separation of reaction products, but CH4 is a waste product, that’s why a decrease in CH4 selectivity is an important task in the development of CO2-FT catalysts. It is also worth mentioning that catalytic stability should be as good as possible, to achieve a high degree of sustainability for the catalyst; in detail, the catalyst should resist deactivation by high temperatures, high water concentration, coke deposition etc. In addition, there are technical requirements regarding the operation in three-phase bubble column reactors. In this reactor type, catalyst particles are subjected to mechanical stress. Accordingly, the catalyst should have high mechanical strength and frictional resistance under such a harsh environment. The knowledge on particle size distribution of the employed catalyst before and after operation provide insight on mechanical stability. A decrease in the mean particle size or an increase in unwanted fine particles (< 10 µm) can cause malfunction in downstream processes and has to be avoided. It is also worth noting that, catalyst structure, density and particle size may change during reduction and the carbidization of the catalyst that also should be taken into account [38]. Moreover, the operation in three-phase bubble column reactor also restricts the maximum size and density of catalyst particles, as the required fluidization should be maintained. Typically, particle sizes between 10 and 100 µm are employed to address both a homogeneous operation regime and a reduced mass transfer resistance between liquid and solid as well inside the catalysts [39]. Accordingly, a fluid dynamic density, i.e. density of catalyst filled with liquid, below 3 g·cm−3 is desirable. Because the fresh catalysts usually represent a mixture of oxides, they should be reduced before using them in CO2-FT. According to the database of CO2 hydrogenation catalysts for hydrocarbon production [23], the reduction in H2 is the most popular procedure of the catalyst pretreatment. A mixture of CO and H2 can also be applied for reducing the fresh catalysts, whereby the temperature of the reduction can be lowered, which is especially important if the catalysts are reduced in-situ in three-phase bubble column reactors. Concluding, the following requirements should be met in the development of CO2-FT catalysts: • High activity to CO2 conversion. • High selectivity to higher hydrocarbons and olefins as well as low selectivity to CH4 and CO. • High stability and frictional resistance (particle size in a range 10–100 μm). • Required fluid dynamic density (not higher 3 g·cm−3). • Low temperature for catalyst pre-treatment (reduction). 2.2 Catalyst development strategy The first stage of the CO2-FTS is the RWGS reaction which is thermodynamically limited. Thermodynamic analysis of the RWGS reaction performed in the work [9] indicates that higher temperature is more preferable for high conversion. So, the equilibrium conversion is around 23% at 300 °C and can be increased up 45% at 450 °C (in the case of CO2:H2 ratio = 1:3). However, on the one hand, higher reaction temperature promotes the carbon deposition on the catalyst surface resulting from the Boudouard reaction (Eq. 1): (1) 2CO ⇄ C + CO2, ∆ r H 523 K ° = -174 kJ·mol−1 which leads to catalyst deactivation. Hence, a temperature above 360 °C should be avoided [9]. Similarly, Brübach et al. observed [40] an increased deactivation rate at 320 °C compared to temperatures below 300 °C. Moreover, it is worth mentioning that the observed CO2 conversion in CO2-FTS can be higher than RWGS equilibrium conversion (for example, 44% for the Fe-K-Mn catalyst in work [11]). This is related to the CO-FT reaction which shifts the equilibrium conversion of the RWGS reaction due to CO consumption. Besides, the CO-FT reaction is kinetically limited, and hydrocarbon selectivity can be described by the Anderson-Schulz-Flory (ASF) distribution (Eq. 2) [41–43]: (2) W n = n 1 − α 2 α n − 1 where n – carbon number; W n – mass fraction of hydrocarbon with carbon number n ; α – the chain growth probability that is defined as a ratio between the rate of the chain prolongation and the sum of the chain prolongation and termination rates [44,45]. Since the ASF distribution depends only on one parameter α, there are direct correlations between the values of selectivity for different hydrocarbons C1, C2 etc. as well as the ranges of C2-C4, C5+ etc., whereas higher values of α corresponds to lower CH4 selectivity and higher C2+ or C5+ selectivity. Besides the hydrocarbon formation via FT reactions (CO-FT and CO2-FT), an undesired route of methane formation from CO2 (CO2 + 4 H2 ⇄ CH4 + 2 H2O, methanation, ∆ r H 523 K ° = −176 kJ·mol−1) was observed [46–49]. Suppressing this route is highly desirable since it will lead to an increase in selectivity to the desired products. The direct pathway of methane formation also leads to a deviation (for C1) from the ideal ASF distribution. In our previous work about the data analysis of CO2 hydrogenation catalysts [23], we have introduced an empirical parameter – an excess-methane selectivity γ to describe this deviation from the ASF. This parameter γ can be calculated from the catalytic data about hydrocarbon distribution. The physical meaning of γ is that it describes the fraction of methane which is formed via the methanation reaction. For example, a γ value of 5% means that 5% of CO2 is converted to CH4 via methanation as well as 95% of CO2 is converted to hydrocarbons via FT reactions. Thus, to develop selective CO2-FT catalysts to higher hydrocarbons, the chain growth probability α and an excess to methane selectivity γ should be taken into account. Specifically, we should strive to increase α and decrease γ. The performed data analysis of the literature of CO2 hydrogenation catalysts showed that the key parameters of catalyst selectivity α and γ only slightly depend on reaction conditions and are predominantly defined by the catalyst. This conclusion is useful and can be used in the screening of highly selective CO2-FT catalysts. Hence, we can compare the catalysts by using these parameters at a reference condition to identify the catalyst ability to produce higher hydrocarbons. Thus, there is no need to measure catalytic activity at a wide range of reaction conditions. Moreover, the previous data analysis also demonstrated [23] that doping Fe-based catalysts with alkali metals is the most effective measure for improving catalyst performance. Accordingly, we focused our attention on the development of Fe-based catalysts promoted by K, which is the most perspective promoter. The first part of the present work presents a screening of the catalyst preparation methods in order to fulfil the aforementioned prerequisites. Using the most suited preparation method, we then screened the catalyst composition and reduction pre-pretreatment conditions. 3 Experimental part 3.1 Catalyst synthesis The Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(IWI) catalyst was prepared via incipient wetness impregnation. γ-Al2O3 (Alfa Aesar, 99%, 32–63 µm, APS Powder) was used as support. Briefly, γ-Al2O3 was first impregnated with the required amount of an aqueous solution containing Fe(NO3)3⋅9 H2O (Fluka, 98%), Cu(NO3)2⋅3 H2O (Fluka, 99%) and K2CO3 (Merck, 99%) to obtain the weight ratio Fe:Cu:K = 10:1:2.5 with 13.5% overall amount of metal in the catalyst. After that, the slurry was dried at 70 °C for 12 h and 110 °C for 5 h and heated up to 400 °C with a heating rate of 3.3 K·min−1 followed by calcination in static air at 400 °C for 5 h. The Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(PD) catalyst with weight ratio Fe:Cu:K = 10:1:2.5 with 13.5% overall amount of metal in the catalyst was prepared via one-pot photo-deposition method [50,51] by decomposition of 2,2’-bipyridinyl metal complexes to achieve the deposition of single sites or nano cluster following by the incipient wetness impregnation of the obtained solid using aqueous solution of K2CO3. The principal scheme of the catalyst preparation using photo-deposition method is presented in the Fig. 1. Briefly, in the first beaker the required amount of FeSO4·7 H2O (Sigma Aldrich, 99%) and CuCl2·2 H2O (ChemPur, 99%) to obtain the weight ratio Fe:Cu = 10:1 were dissolved at room temperature in as little de-ionized water as possible. In the second beaker 3.01 equivalents of 2,2’-bipyridine (TCI, 99%) related to the total molar amount of the metals were dissolved in 15 ml ethanol. 4.33 g of γ-Al2O3 (Alfa Aesar, 99%, 32–63 µm, APS Powder) was weighed into a separate beaker and 410 ml acetonitrile (Fisher, 99.5%) was added to completely suspend the support. Afterwards 2,2’-bipyridine solution was added to the suspension of γ-Al2O3 and CH3CN followed by adding of metal solution to form Fe- and Cu-complex in situ (color change to deep red). Subsequently, 275 ml triethylamine and CH3CN (Fisher, 99%) were added to yield a mixture in the total volumetric ratio CH3CN:N(C2H5)3 = 3:2. Finally, the reaction vessel was transferred to a stirring plate in front of the Xe-lamp (LOT-QuantumDesign, LSE341). The reaction mixture was irradiated with 300 W Xe light for 24 h under stirring. The focus point of the Xe beam should be at half height of the reaction volume. Finally, the suspension was filtrated under vacuum, followed by washing with water and acetonitrile. The solid was dried at 110 °C for 5 h and calcined at 400 °C (3.3 K·min−1) for 5 h in air. Potassium was then added by incipient wetness impregnation, using the required amount of an aqueous solution containing K2CO3 (Merck, 99%). After that, the solid was dried at 110 °C for 5 h and heated up to 400 °C with a heating rate of 3.3 K·min−1 followed by the calcination at 400 °C for 5 h (all steps in static air). The Fe-Al-Cu-K(CP) catalyst was prepared with a weight ratio Fe:Al2O3:Cu:K = 100:13:10:25 by a coprecipitation method. In detail, the required amount of metal nitrates Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O (Fluka, 98%), Al(NO3)3·9 H2O (Alfa Aesar, 97%) and Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O (Glentham, 99%) were dissolved in de-ionized water using a weight ratio of metal precursors:water = 1:0.75. The aqueous solution was heated up under stirring until strong steam development under the boiling point followed by quickly addition of 25% NH3 aqueous solution. The obtained slurry was filtered and the obtained solid was washed two times with 25 ml deionized water at room temperature. The washed sample was dried at 50 °C overnight. Finally, potassium was added to the obtained solid by incipient wetness impregnation using an aqueous solution of K2CO3 (Merck, 99%). After impregnation the sample was dried at 100 °C for 5 h and heated up to 400 °C with a heating rate of 3.3 K·min−1 followed by calcination at 400 °C for 5 h (all steps in static air). Another Fe-Al-Cu-K(PM) catalyst with the same weight ratio Fe:Al2O3:Cu:K = 100:13:10:25 was prepared by the Pechini method [52]. Anhydrous citric acid (Sigma Aldrich, ≥99.5%) was used as organic compound. The desired amount of metal nitrates Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O (Fluka, 98+ %), KNO3 (J.T. Baker, 99+ %), Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O (Fluka, 99+ %) and Al(NO3)3·9 H2O (Alfa Aesar, 97+ %) were dissolved in de-ionized water in a single beaker. Citric acid was added with a molar ratio of metal precursors:citric acid = 1:1 followed by the addition of ethylene glycol (Carl Roth, ≥ 99%) with molar ratio of metal precursors: ethylene glycol = 1:2. Water was evaporated at 110 °C from the resulting solution by stirring on a hot plate. The paste was then dried at 110 °C for 8 h and heated up to 200 °C (0.4 K·min−1) in static air. After cooling down, the resulting solid was ground to fine powder which was subsequently heated in static air up to 800 °C with a heating rate of 3.3 K·min−1 followed by calcination at 800 °C for 4 h. Yet another Fe-Al-Cu-K(OC) catalyst with the weight ratio Fe:Al2O3:Cu:K = 100:13:10:25 was prepared by organic combustion method [11]. Metal nitrates Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O (Fluka, 98+ %), KNO3 (J.T. Baker, 99+ %), Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O (Fluka, 99+ %) and Al(NO3)3·9 H2O (Alfa Aesar, 97+ %) were used for the catalyst preparation. The required amount of each nitrate salt to obtain the weight ratio Fe:Al2O3:Cu:K = 100:13:10:25 and anhydrous citric acid (Sigma Aldrich, ≥ 99.5%) were dissolved in de-ionized water in a single beaker. Citric acid was added with molar ratio of Fe-precursor:citric acid = 1:1 and the mass of the water was equal to the half of the mass of ´metal precursors + citric acid`. The solution was stirred under the fume hood on a heating plate for 1–2 h at 110 °C to remove water with evolution of NOx gas resulting from decomposition of nitrate. The paste was then dried at 110 °C for 8 h in the muffle furnace and afterwards heated up to 200 °C with a heating rate of 0.4 K·min−1 in static air until self-ignition. The solid was ground into a fine powder and heated up to 600 °C with a heating rate of 10 K·min−1 followed by the calcination at 600 °C for 4 h in static air. The organic combustion method was also used for preparing a series of the catalysts with different compositions (see Table 1). 3.2 Catalyst characterization To determine the surface area of the catalysts, low-temperature nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained at −196 °C using a BELSORP-max II (BEL Japan, Inc.) instrument. Before the measurements, the samples were heated in vacuum at 250 °C for 2 h. The initial branch of N2 adsorption isotherm in the range of P/P0 (0.05–0.25) was used to calculate the BET surface area. The mass fraction of elements (Fe, K etc.) in the catalysts was determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) on Varian 715-ES ICP-Emission-Spectrometer. 10 mg of each sample were mixed with 8 ml of aqua regia. The sample preparation system “Multiwave PRO” from Anton Paar was used at 220 °C and 50 bar for the sample digestion with a microwave-assisted method. The digested solution was filled up to 100 ml and measured with ICP-OES. The data analysis was performed on the Varian 715-ES software “ICP Expert”. To determine mass fraction of elements in the spent catalysts operated in a slurry reactor, around 2 g of the samples were washed with around 100 ml of n-decan using Buchner funnel filtration. The obtained precipitates were dried at 200 °C for 1 hour, heated up to 600 °C with a heating rate of 10 K·min−1 followed by the calcination at 600 °C for 4 h in static air. X-ray diffraction (XRD) powder pattern were recorded on a Panalytical X’Pert θ/2θ -diffractometer equipped with an Xcelerator detector using automatic divergence slits and Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 40 mA; λ= 0.15406 nm) and on a Stoe Stadi P transmission diffractometer equipped with a DECTRIS Mythen2 1 K detector applying Ge (111) monochromatized Mo Ka1 radiation (50 kV, 40 mA, 0.07093 nm). Cu beta-radiation was excluded using a nickel filter foil. The measurements were performed with 0.005 °·s−1. Samples were mounted on silicon zero background holders. Obtained intensities were converted from automatic to fixed divergence slits (0.25 °) for further analysis. Peak positions and profiles were fitted with Pseudo-Voigt function using the HighScore Plus software package (Panalytical). Phase identification was done by using the PDF-2 database of the International Center of Diffraction Data (ICDD). Crystallite size was calculated by applying the Scherrer equation using the integral width under the assumption of spherically shaped crystallites. Temperature-programmed reduction with hydrogen (TPR-H2) was done using a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 instrument. 50 mg or 75 mg of sample were loaded in a U-shaped quartz reactor and heated from RT (room temperature, 25 °C) to 250 °C with a heating rate of 20 K min−1 in Ar (50 ml·min−1), calcined for 30 min at 250 °C, then cooled down to RT and flushing the sample with Ar. Each TPR run was carried out from RT to 750 °C in a 5% H2/Ar flow (50 ml·min−1) with a heating rate of 10 K·min−1. The final temperature of 750 °C was held for 30 or 60 min. A thermal conductivity detector was used to determine the H2 concentration in the outlet gas stream. Samples were analyzed by a field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, MERLIN® VP Compact, Co. Zeiss, Oberkochen, Germany) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) detector (Xflash 6/30, Co. Bruker, Berlin, Germany). Before that, samples were mounted on heavy metal-free Al-SEM-carrier (co. PLANO, Wetzlar, Germany) with adhesive conductive carbon tape (Spectro Tabs, TED PELLA INC, Redding, USA) and coated with carbon (5.0 nm thickness) under vacuum (CCU 010 HV-Coating Unit, Co. Safematic GmbH, Zizers, Switzerland). Representative areas of the samples were analyzed and mapped for elemental distribution on basis of the EDX-spectra data by QUANTAX ESPRIT Microanalysis software (version 2.0). SEM-images were taken from the selected regions. Catalysts used in the slurry reactor were subjected to particle size measurements before and after operation using laser diffraction and dynamic image analysis with Bettersizer S3 Plus [53,54]. Wet samples were diluted and dispersed in squalane (ACROS Organics, 99%); the liquid phase employed in the slurry reactor. The fluid dynamic density ( ρ f ) was calculated using the particle density ρ s , pore volume V pore and the estimated density of the Fischer-Tropsch product (ρ w is about 0.8 kg·l−1) (Eq. 3). It is assumed that all pores of the catalyst are filled with FT products. The particle density ρ s was determined using a pycnometer with an average of 3 measurements. The fluid dynamic density was calculated by the Eq. 4. (3) ρ f = ρ w + ρ s (4) ρ f = V pore · ρ w V pore + 1 ρ s + 1 V pore + 1 ρ s For example, the estimation of the fluid dynamic density ρ f for pure Al2O3 is presented: ρ f ( Al 2 O 3 ) = 0.46 ml · g − 1 · 0.8 g · ml − 1 0.46 ml · g − 1 + 1 3.95 g · ml − 1 + 1 0.46 ml · g − 1 + 1 3.95 g · ml − 1 = 1.92 g · ml − 1 3.3 Catalytic tests in a fixed bed reactor Catalytic tests were carried out in an in-house developed setup containing 16 parallel continuous-flow fixed bed stainless-steel tube reactors. The reactors are grouped in sets of 4. Each of these reactor sets has its own heating; the heating design assures high heat-transfer rates between furnace and reactor tube in order to maintain the set temperature even for more exothermic reactions. The outer and inner diameters of reactors are 9.5 and 7.0 mm, respectively. CO2, H2, N2, and He gases were dosed by electronic mass flow controllers (Brooks 5850 s). The total flow of feed gases was equally distributed among all the reactors and a bypass channel. The outlet lines from reactors are split at 150°C into a main flow and a sample portion. The sample portion is passed to a 16-channels automatic valve to select and direct one stream to an online gas chromatograph through a heated line (kept at 180 °C). A flow of He (3 ml·min−1 per reactor) is additionally added to this sample stream to prevent condensation of long-chain hydrocarbons. The main flows are led through hot traps where a wax phase is condensed at 150 °C. The remaining gas streams are combined and passed through a cold trap where H2O is condensed before they reach the electronic pressure controller (Brooks 5866 s). The catalysts with the fraction of 0.10–0.45 mm were used for catalytic tests. Regardless of the catalyst bed length, an additional layer of SiC (800 mg, ESK-SiC, F54, 0.2–0.5 mm fraction) was added on top to ensure plug flow and to preheat the reaction feed. The feed components (bypass channel) and the reaction products were analyzed by on-line Agilent 7890 A gas chromatograph equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and two flame ionization detectors (FID). HP Plot/Q (for CO2) and MolSieve 5 A (for H2, O2, N2, and CO) columns were connected to TCD. For separating hydrocarbons and alcohols, PONA (for C5-C16 hydrocarbons) and HP Plot/Q (for C1-C4) columns connected to FIDs were used. Before catalytic testing, the as-prepared catalysts were heated up to target temperature in N2 flow and after that were reduced in-situ step by step in 10% H2 in N2 flow for 10 min, in 30% H2 in N2 flow for 10 min, in 50% H2 in N2 flow for 10 min, and finally in either pure H2 or a CO-H2 mixture (CO:H2 was 1:2) for 240 min. Pressure was 1.5 bar (abs.), gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 26470 cm³·h−1·g−1 during the reduction procedure. After the reduction, the catalysts were tested under CO2-FT conditions (CO2:H2:N2 ratio was 1:3:1) at 15 bar and selected temperature (250 or 300 °C). Time on stream was at least 20 h per each condition. The CO2 conversion ( X ) (Eq. 5) and products selectivity (Eq. 6) were calculated by the following equations: (5) X = 1 − n ̇ CO 2 out n ̇ CO 2 in (6) S i = a i · n ̇ i out ∑ j = 1 n a j · n ̇ j out where n ̇ CO 2 in – the molar flow of CO2 in the inlet flow; n ̇ CO 2 out – the molar flow of CO2 in the outlet flow; S i – the selectivity of i-product; a i – the carbon number of i-product; n ̇ i out – the molar flow of i-product in the outlet flow. Carbon balance was established to be higher than 98%. 3.4 Catalytic tests in three-phase slurry reactor Catalytic tests were executed in a re-constructed lab-scale Fischer-Tropsch plant. The experience in building FT plants from previous works [10,55,56] was used for the construction of the present setup. A simplified flow scheme is shown in the Fig. 2. Information on commissioning and preliminary CO2-FT studies can be found in [57]. Substrate gases are supplied from gas cylinders via mass flow controllers (Bronkhorst, El-Flow) and fed to either a stainless-steel fixed bed or stirred tank reactor (Premex, MED 179) with an inner diameter of 75 mm and liquid volume of up to 350 ml. It is capable of reaction conditions up to 300 °C and 60 bar. An in-house fabricated pitched blade impeller with a diameter of 50 mm and baffles provide sufficient agitation powered by a stirrer capable of up to 2 000 min−1 with constant torque measurement (IKA, Ministar 20 control). A ¼” HPLC frit (RESTEK) with 0.5 µm mesh size is mounted on the outlet to keep the dispersed catalyst inside the reactor while liquid and gaseous reaction products can pass through. Separation of the two phases occurs in the hot flash where residence time is high enough to ensure thermodynamic equilibrium at operating conditions. The flash is emptied manually to avoid accumulation of liquid product over a two-valve lock. Pressure control of the plant is realized via back pressure regulator(Pressure Control Solutions, Equilibar LF Series Precision) equipped with PTFE Glass Laminate diaphragm which in turn is pressurized with N2. Hot gases pass the pressure back regulator and in-line diode laser (Mettler Toledo, GPro500) capable of determining H2O concentration in real-time without cross sensitivities. A slip stream is supplied to a two-line online GC with He as carrier gas (Shimadzu, Nexis GC-2030). In the first line, permanent gases (in order of elution H2, CO2, ethylene, ethane, Ar, N2, CH4 and CO) are separated via Hayesep N, Hayesep Q and molsieve 13X columns before being detected on a TCD. Hydrocarbons with higher chain lengths and water are kept in the Hayesep N column before being backflushed into the off-gas. The second line consists of a Rtx-1 capillary column (inner diameter 0.53 mm, film thickness 5.00 µm, length 60 m) to separate hydrocarbons up to C20. Temperature is kept at 40 °C for 6 minutes before the oven heats up by 10 K·min−1 until 270 °C for 30 minutes. Majority of gaseous products are fed to a cold flash with a thermostat (Huber, Minichiller 600) to condensate water. Sampling works with an identical two-valve lock as for the hot flash. The gas phase is passed through an in-line infra-red analyzer (ABB, Uras26) to determine CO and CO2 concentration in real-time before being vented. The entire plant can be controlled via Simatic PLC on-site or remotely. Before catalytic testing, the reactor was equipped with baffles and filled with 10 g of selected catalyst as well as 300 ml of squalane (ACROS Organics, 99%). Stirring speed was set to 800 min−1 and the plant was pressurized with N2 up to 25 bar. Catalysts were reduced in-situ with 200 ml min−1 H2 at 250 °C and 25 bar for up to 24 h or until no H2O could be detected with the tunable diode laser. Activation was performed with a 2:1:1 mixture of H2:CO:Ar with a total flow of 300 ml min−1 for 48 h. Afterwards, the catalysts were tested at the following reaction condition 250 °C, 25 bar, H2:CO2:Ar = 3:1:0.5, GHSV 1800 cm³·g−1·h−1. Time on stream after activation was a least 140 h. An operating point was deemed in steady state if three consecutive GC measurements showed relative deviation of product gas concentrations below 1% or an absolute deviation below 0.01 mol.%. The CO2 conversion and product selectivity were calculated by the Eqs. 5 and 6, respectively. Carbon balance was established to be higher than 98%. 4 Results and discussion 4.1 The evaluation of catalyst preparation methods The first task of the current study was to perform the evaluation of the catalyst preparation methods. The Fe-K-Cu-Al catalyst suggested by Hans Schulz et al. [58] was chosen as a benchmark. Based on the composition of this catalyst, we prepared a series of the catalysts with similar composition using (i) incipient wetness impregnation, (ii) photo-deposition, (iii) co-precipitation, (iv) organic combustion, and (v) Pechini methods. The catalytic performance of the obtained catalysts tested under different reaction conditions is presented in Table 2 along with the values of the fluid dynamic density. This table represents the typical catalytic data of the CO2-FT catalysts. The complexity in analysis of such data is caused by the presence of a lot of different catalytic parameters like CO2 conversion, CO and hydrocarbons selectivity, olefins content etc. Our strategy is based on comparing the catalysts in terms of their ability to produce higher hydrocarbons by evaluating the chain growth probability α and in terms of excess to methane selectivity γ. Higher α and lower γ correspond to higher ability of the catalyst to produce C5+ hydrocarbons and lower CH4 selectivity. Wherein, these parameters only slightly depend on reaction condition and, thus, one catalytic experimental condition is enough to screen the catalysts for their ability to selectively produce higher hydrocarbons. For example, the C5+ selectivity at 300 °C and GHSV of 2550 cm3·g−1·h−1 for the catalyst prepared by Pechini method is 14.6% and lower than for the catalyst obtained by the wet impregnation method (C5+ selectivity is 16.5%). However, the ability to produce higher hydrocarbons for the first catalyst is higher than for the second one because the chain growth probability α are 0.65 and 0.53, respectively, because the difference in C5+ selectivity is caused by the difference in CO2 conversion. From the presented data (Table 2), one can clearly see that the chain growth probability α for each catalyst only slightly depends on reaction temperature and GHSV as well as the reduction pretreatment. The values of α are in a range from 0.50 to 0.54 in the case of the catalyst prepared by wet impregnation method whereas for the catalyst obtained by the organic combustion method α is 0.70–0.71, which agrees with the conclusion made in the data analysis of CO2-FT catalysts [23]. The distribution of the hydrocarbons formed in CO2 hydrogenation over the selected catalysts is presented in the Figure S1. It is also worth noting that there is no influence of the reduction condition on the chain growth probability (H2 or CO-H2 mixture, reduction temperature). However, the usage of CO-H2 is of advantage from technological point of view because it allows lower reduction temperatures especially suitable for in-situ reduction in slurry phase (250 < 400 °C). In the case of parameter γ, similar trends are observed except for the presence of a slight correlation between γ and CO2 conversion (lower values of γ correspond to higher conversion in the catalyst prepared by co-precipitation method, for example). Moreover, it is worth noting the inverse correlation between the parameters α and γ and can be seen in Figure S2. Thus, the contribution of the methanation reaction is lower when the catalyst has higher chain growth probability; this is the case for all investigated catalysts. Our data clearly demonstrate an influence of the preparation method on the chain growth probability α and an excess to methane selectivity γ of the studied catalysts (Table 2). Specifically, the chain growth probability decreases (an excess to methane selectivity increases) in the following order of the catalyst preparation methods: organic combustion > co-precipitation ∼ Pechini >> incipient wetness impregnation > photo-deposition. Besides, higher values of α go along with higher contents of olefins in the products of CO2-FTS and lower selectivity to CH4. Thus, from the catalytic point of view, the organic combustion method is the most promising method compared to the other preparation methods studied in the present work. It is also interesting that the bulk catalysts are more selective in producing higher hydrocarbons compared to the supported catalysts, because α are 0.65–0.71 and 0.42–0.54 for the bulk and supported catalysts, respectively (γ are 9.0–19.3% and 0.1–8.2% for the supported and bulk catalysts, respectively). The reason of this phenomena is discussed later. Apart from the catalytic performance, one of the most important parameters of CO2-FT catalysts operating in the three-phases bubble column reactor is the fluid dynamic density. In case of the benchmark catalyst prepared by co-precipitation method, the fluid dynamic density is 3.78 g·cm−3 and well above the limit value (> 3.0 g·cm−3). However, in case of the other preparation methods, we were able to obtain catalysts that reach required values of the fluid dynamic density. We conclude that the catalyst obtained from the organic combustion method, possessing a fluid dynamic density of 2.57 g·cm−3, could be the most promising synthesis with respect to catalytic performance as well as material properties required for application in slurry reactors. The pre-treatment of the catalysts with a CO-H2 mixture is preferred since it allows to carry out activation at lower temperature. 4.2 Screening of the catalyst composition and reduction conditions In this part of work, we investigated the influence of the catalyst composition and the temperature of the reduction pre-treatment on the catalytic properties of the catalysts prepared by the organic combustion method. Table 1 shows the list of all catalysts prepared by the organic combustion method with information on theoretical and experimental (measured for the several catalysts by ICP) compositions. One can see that the element content in the obtained catalysts measured by ICP corresponds to the theoretical content. The detailed information on catalytic performance (CO2 conversion, hydrocarbons selectivity, olefins content etc.) for the studied catalysts is given in Table S1. From the presented data one can see that the chain growth probability α is high in comparison with other CO2-FT catalysts and in a range of 0.66–0.70 for all K-promoted catalysts (the excess to methane selectivity γ was not higher than 7.4%). In the case of an unpromoted Fe catalyst used as a baseline sample, the value of α was much lower with only 0.46–0.47 and the value of γ was much higher (around 25%). The low α and high γ also contribute both to the high selectivity to CH4 (> 30%) for the pure Fe catalyst. The observed effect of doping Fe-based with K agreed with the early published works [27,59,60] which reported a positive effect of K on higher hydrocarbon selectivity in CO2-FT. It is interesting to note that the chain growth probability α for the Fe-K-based catalysts doped by Al or Cu (but not both Al and Cu) is 0.67–0.69 and slightly lower than the α for the catalysts promoted by both Al and Cu (α = 0.69–0.70) which may indicate a synergetic effect of Al and Cu on improving the selectivity to higher hydrocarbons. The observed synergic effect was statistically proved by Student’s t-test [61] (the estimated p-value was 2.3·10−3). However, it is worth mentioning that this effect is weak and does not lead to a significant rise in the chain growth probability α compared to the effect of K. It also agrees with the results of data analysis of CO2 hydrogenation that alkaline metals have a stronger effect on the chain growth probability compared to other promoters [23]. Moreover, the fraction of oxygenates (mainly alcohols) for Cu-promoted catalysts is 7.8–8.4% and clearly higher compared to Cu-free catalysts (oxygenate fraction is 0.5–4.5%, see Table S1). Thus, doping Fe-based catalyst with Cu increases the ability of catalyst to produce alcohols which is consistent with a previous work [62]. Except for the influence of dopants on hydrocarbon distribution and alcohols formation, promoters also increase the overall activity of the Fe-based catalysts. Fig. 3 presents dependencies between CO2 conversion and the composition of the obtained catalysts reduced at 250 °C and 300 °C. One can see that doping with K, Al, and Cu increases the overall CO2 conversion in the case of high reduction temperature (300 °C). However, in the case of low reduction temperature (250 °C), only Cu-containing catalysts maintain high activity for CO2 conversion at a level comparable to the activity of the catalysts reduced at 300 °C. For the K-doped catalysts without Cu, a strong decrease in CO2 conversion was observed (from ∼35 to ∼25%). Besides, we can see an opposite trend in the influence of Al on the overall activity of the catalysts reduced at different temperature and doped with K and Cu. So, an increase and a decrease in CO2 conversion with a rising Al content were observed in the case of reduction temperatures at 300 and 250 °C, respectively. Thus, based on the obtained results, we identified the 100Fe25K10Cu13Al catalyst as the most promising candidate for CO2-FTS among the catalysts investigated in the present work. To compare the activity and selectivity of the catalysts studied here with literature, the database of CO2 hydrogenation catalysts [23] was used. Fig. 4 presents the dependency between the product selectivity and CO2 conversion for the prepared catalysts and the literature data. One can see that the catalysts in this work have low selectivity to CO and CH4 as well as high selectivity to target products and are competitive with the most active/selective catalysts reported in the literature. Thus, the suggested strategy of catalyst development based on the knowledge obtained from the data analysis of CO2 hydrogenation catalysts combined with fast parallel testing allowed one to develop and identify CO2-FT catalysts with satisfying high selectivity to target products and activity to CO2 conversion. 4.3 Catalyst characterization The analysis of the catalytic data demonstrated that the supported catalysts are less selective for the production of higher hydrocarbons compared to the bulk catalysts. To understand the observed phenomena, we investigated several representative catalysts, (Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(IWI), Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) and Fe-Al-K-Cu(CP) using physico-chemical methods. The textural properties of the selected catalysts are presented in Table 3. In addition, the properties of the pure γ-Al2O3 support are also presented. The surface area SBET of the support is high and around 216 m2·g−1 which is typical for meso-porous γ-Al2O3 [63]. The supported Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(IWI) catalyst also has high SBET of 193 m2·g−1. Besides the slight decrease in the surface area, a decrease in pore volume and pore size is also observed for the supported catalyst compared to the pure alumina. For both bulk catalysts, the surface area SBET is much lower and around 10–30 m2·g−1. However, referring to the catalytic data presented in Table 2, the activities of the bulk catalysts are significantly higher than those of the supported catalyst when comparing the CO2 conversion values measured at similar reaction conditions. For example, we have observed 41.4% of CO2 conversion for the Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) catalyst, 32.0% of CO2 conversion for the Fe-Al-K-Cu(CP) catalyst versus 26.9% of CO2 conversion for the Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(IWI) catalyst, all tested under the same conditions at 300 °C and GHSV 5100 cm³·g−1·h−1. This result of higher activity at lower surface area is due to the fact that the specific surface area determined from the low-temperature N2 adsorption is only a physical overall surface areas but not a measure of accessible active sites. Thus, a lower number of active sites for should be assumed for the Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(IWI) than for the Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) catalyst despite its higher surface area. To analyze the phase composition of the catalysts, XRD analysis was performed. Fig. 5 shows XRD patterns for the obtained fresh catalysts. According to the XRD pattern (Fig. 5A), the supported Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(IWI) catalyst contains, in addition to γ-Al2O3, the phase of Fe2O3 hematite (PDF 01–076–8402) which is indicated by the corresponding reflections. The domain size of Fe2O3 calculated by the Scherrer equation was 14 nm. No K- or Cu-containing phases were detected in the supported catalyst. The bulk Fe-Al-K-Cu(CP) catalyst (Fig. 5B) also contains the phase of hematite with a domain size being 24 nm. In addition, the phase of KNO3 (PDF 01–074–2055) was identified in this sample that could be formed during the catalyst preparation. The small peak is observed at 27.0° that may be attributed to the presence of KNO2 (00–022–0840) phase in the bulk Fe-Al-K-Cu(CP) catalyst. No Cu- or Al-containing phases were detected in this XRD pattern, too. In case of the bulk catalyst prepared by the organic combustion method (Fig. 5C), Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) contains mainly a cubic Fe3O4 phase (PDF 01–084–2782), monoclinic KHCO3 (PDF 01–070–0995) and trace amount of hexagonal carbon (PDF 01–075–1621). The estimated crystallite size of Fe3O4 phase was 28 nm. No Cu- or Al-containing phases could be detected here. It is worth noting that the domain size of iron oxide for the supported catalyst was lower (14 nm) than for the bulk ones (24 nm and 28 nm for Fe-Al-K-Cu(CP) and Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC), respectively). XRD patterns of the spent catalysts after testing in a fixed bed (reduction treatment in CO-H2 mixture at 300 °C; reaction conditions – CO2:H2:N2 was 1:3:1; temperature was 300 °C; GHSV was 5100 cm3·g−1·h−1; time on stream was 20 h) are presented in Fig. 6. The spent Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(IWI) catalyst consists of γ-Al2O3 and the phase of a cubic Fe3O4 (PDF 01–084–2782). No K- or Cu-containing phases were detected in the supported spent catalyst. The absence of the phase of iron carbides as an essential active component for catalyzing FT reaction [10–12] can be explained by its low concentration in the sample. The spent Fe-Al-K-Cu(CP) catalyst consists of mainly cubic Fe3O4 (PDF 01–084–2782). Additional peaks at 17.82 °, 18.47 °, 20.31 °, and 35.23 ° indicate the presence of monoclinic Fe5C2 (PDF 01–079–0417). The small peak at 22.58 ° may be attributed to the presence of metallic Cu (PDF 00–004–0836). The mixture of iron carbide and oxide was also found in the spent Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) catalyst. In addition, the sharp peaks at 24.39 °, 26.53 °, and 28.90 ° are observed that is related to the presence of hexagonal α-SiO2 (PDF 01–087–2096) in the spent sample. This is due to the fact that the spent samples are difficult to separate from the SiC (ESK-SiC, F54) which was used as pre-bed in the catalytic tests. Moreover, two additional peaks at 9.87 ° and 10.95 ° were found in the spent Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) catalyst that can be attributed to n-paraffin (PDF 00–040–1995) and thus the FT wax formed during CO2 hydrogenation. It is worth noting that the FT wax is only observed in the spent Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) catalyst which had the highest the chain growth probability α among all investigated catalysts. The domain sizes of the main phases in the spent catalysts were calculated by the Scherrer equation and are presented in Table 4. The domain size of iron oxides for the fresh catalysts is also presented including the crystallite size of Fe2O3 in the fresh supported Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(PD) catalyst prepared by the photo-deposition method (see Figure S3 for its XRD pattern). From the presented data one can see that a decrease in the crystallite size of iron oxides in the fresh catalysts has the following order: Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) > Fe-Al-K-Cu(CP) > Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(IWI). This order in crystallite size of Fe3O4 remains the same for the spent catalysts. For the domain size of iron carbide, which was detected only in the spent bulk catalysts, both Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) and Fe-Al-K-Cu(CP) catalyst have the same order of magnitude of the crystallite size of Fe5C2. Selected regions of the Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(IWI), Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC), and Fe-Al-K-Cu(CP) catalysts were analyzed by SEM and the elemental distribution was determined based on the EDX spectra (Figure S4-S6). It can be clearly seen that the distribution of Fe, K, Al, and Cu in the obtained catalysts is quite homogeneous. However, some areas show an inhomogeneous distribution of Fe in the case of the Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(IWI) and K in the case of the Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(CP) catalysts. In addition to element distribution, we can see needle-shaped structures in the SEM picture of the Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(OC) catalyst. To investigate the reducibility of the obtained catalyst, TPR-H2 measurements were performed (see Fig. 7). The reduction of Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(IWI) catalyst (blue curve) takes place in a wide temperature range from 200 to 750 °C. The area under the TPR-H2 curve corresponds to the H2 consumption during the TPR-H2 measurement. The temperatures of maximum H2 consumption (T max) were found at 312, 360 and 542 °C. According to the literature, the process of reducing Fe2O3 proceeds in three steps (Fe2O3→Fe3O4→FeO→Fe) [64–66]. In addition, it is known that copper oxide is reduced at lower temperature compared to Fe2O3 in mixed CuO-Fe2O3 catalysts [67]. Thus, the double peak at lower temperature (T max = 312 °C and T max = 360 °C) is due to the reduction of CuO to Cu and Fe2O3 to Fe3O4. The reduction of Fe3O4 to FeO/Fe is responsible for the broad peak at higher temperatures with T max = 542 °C. A similar pattern is observed in the TPR-H2 curves for the bulk Fe-Al-K-Cu(CP) and Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) catalysts. The first peak corresponds to the reduction of CuO→Cu (the maxima are 373 and 364 °C for Fe-Al-K-Cu(CP) and Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC), respectively). An additional peak with a maximum at 438 °C is observed in the case of the bulk Fe-Al-K-Cu(CP) catalyst. This peak is likely related to the reduction Fe2O3→Fe3O4. The absence of such peak in TPR-H2 for Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) is explained by the result of the XRD analysis where only Fe3O4 is observed in this catalyst. The further broad peak (at 500–700 °C) can be attributed to the reduction Fe3O4→FeO/Fe. Herein, it is worth mentioning that the temperature of the reduction of Fe2O3→Fe3O4 for the supported catalyst is lower than for bulk catalyst (T max are 360 °C and 438 for °C Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(IWI) and Fe-Al-K-Cu(CP) catalysts, respectively). Such a difference may be explained by the smaller size of the Fe2O3 in the supported catalyst compared to the bulk catalysts, (see calculated domain sizes). Thus, a lower reduction temperature in TPR-H2 also indicates smaller particle size of the active component in the supported catalyst compared to the bulk catalysts. The difference in the particle size of iron oxide may also explain the difference in the selectivity of our catalysts. Our catalysts show a linear correlation between the chain growth probability α and the crystallite size of iron oxides (see Fig. 8). Thus, smaller particle size of the active component in the supported catalysts may be responsible for lower selectivity to higher hydrocarbons. This interpretation is in line with Jie Zhu et al. [49] who investigated the effect of particle size of supported Fe-based catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation to hydrocarbons. They found that for K-promoted Fe-based catalysts a decrease in a particle size of iron oxide in the catalysts led to a decrease in C5+ selectivity measured at similar CO2 conversion. 4.4 Catalytic performance in 3-phase slurry reactor The final part of the present work was to evaluate the catalysts in a three-phase reactor. The supported Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(IWI) and bulk Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) catalysts were selected for catalytic tests to compare the best performing supported and bulk catalyst from this work. The catalytic performance of the obtained catalysts after 140 h of operation is presented in Table 5. CO2 conversion and C2+ selectivity for the supported Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(IWI) catalyst were much lower than for bulk Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC), implying higher RWGS and FT activity for the latter. The obtained results agree with the catalytic results in the fixed bed reactor (see Table 2) where we observed that bulk catalysts are more active and selective towards higher hydrocarbons in CO2-FTS than the supported ones. For both tests the activity over time on stream is given in the supplementary information (see Figure S7). From this data no deactivation, i.e. decrease in conversion or selectivity, could be deduced. Moreover, the catalyst prepared by the organic combustion method operated very close to the equilibrium composition of the RWGS at 250 °C implying the reaction rate of FT being the limiting one to the production of hydrocarbons. To support this statement, we estimated an approach to equilibrium of the RWGS reaction by estimating the thermodynamic ratio η [68] that is defined by the following Eq. 7: (7) η = p CO p H 2 O p CO 2 p H 2 1 K RWGS where p i is partial pressure of i-compound in the outlet of slurry reactor; K RWGS – equilibrium constant of the RWGS reaction [40]. In the case of thermodynamic equilibrium, the ratio η is equal to 1. The obtained value of η was 0.82 which indicates that the Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) catalyst was operated close to equilibrium of the RWGS. For the supported catalyst, the ratio η was estimated to be around 0.13 that is far from equilibrium. Chain growth probabilities for both catalysts were similar when switching the testing setup indicating that the in-situ activation procedure in the slurry reactor was successful. Moreover, changing concentrations of substrates (CO2, H2, CO etc., dissolved in the squalene) at the catalyst surface did not seem to alter its ability for chain growth. It is worth noting that this change in the substrate concentration is related to a the slurry reactor being a completely back-mixed system (i) and to different solubility of the substrates in liquid phase, squalane (ii) [69]. Thus, the ratio of CO2:H2 concentration at the catalyst surface is different in a fixed bed (where substrates react with the surface form the gas phase) and slurry (from the liquid phase). The distribution of the hydrocarbons formed in CO2 hydrogenation in the slurry reactor is presented in the Figure S8. Interestingly, the olefin fraction in the products of CO2 hydrogenation after the slurry reactor was much lower, whereas the oxygenate fraction was much higher compared to the results of catalytic tests in a fixed bed reactor. So, in the case of slurry reactor, the fraction of olefin and oxygenates for bulk Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) catalyst were 38.2% and 34.3%, respectively. However, the olefin fraction for the catalysts obtained by the organic combustion method and tested in a fixed bed reactor were a least not lower than 74% (the oxygenate fraction was not higher than 8%). Longer residence times of unsaturated hydrocarbons in the slurry may result in their readsorption and additional secondary reactions leading to oxygenated products [70]. In the case of supported Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(IWI), the main oxygenated product was methanol (CH3OH selectivity was 16% in slurry). For bulk Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) catalyst, ethanol was the main one with 10% selectivity (in slurry). This seems to be in-line with findings in the field of mixed alcohols synthesis on Fe-based catalysts. Potassium as a promoter was shown to enhance the chemisorption of CO and reduce that of H2, increasing the yield of alcohols [71]. To compare the obtained catalytic results with the literature, Table 5 includes the performance of CO2-FT catalysts tested in a slurry reactor reported in the works [17,34,72,73]. Comparing the catalytic data is possible only to a limited extend due to the different reaction conditions. However, from the presented data, one can still see that the bulk Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) catalyst demonstrates comparable CO2 conversion and selectivity to higher hydrocarbons with decreased production of undesired methane (selectivity is less 10%) еven though this catalyst was tested at a lower temperature. Thus, the obtained Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) catalyst has a potential as an active and selective one for CO2-FTS. To investigate possible leaching of active components during CO2 hydrogenation in the slurry reactor, we determine the elemental composition of the fresh and spent catalysts. The obtained results are presented in the Table S3. From the presented data we conclude that no significant loss of active components occurs during operation in the slurry reactor in the case of both supported and bulk catalysts. In addition to the catalyst activity and selectivity, the mechanical strength is an important parameter of CO2-FT catalysts operating in a slurry reactor. To investigate the resistance of the obtained catalysts against attrition, we performed measurements of the particle size by laser diffraction for the fresh and spent (after testing in a slurry reactor) catalysts. The analysis of the particle size distribution can provide not only data regarding mechanical strength ability but can also give additional information about mechanisms of catalyst attrition. The main mechanisms of catalyst attrition include: (i) fragmentation via the particle fracture and (ii) abrasive wear from the particle surface [74]. The particle size distributions for the obtained catalysts are presented in Fig. 9. As can be seen, the particle size distribution for supported fresh catalyst is narrow with an explicit maximum at around 59 μm. In the case of fresh Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) catalyst, a small tail in 3–20 μm is observed in addition to the maximum at around 52 μm. The mean particle size of fresh Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(IWI) catalyst is 61.0 μm and slightly higher than for Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) catalyst with 52.2 μm. This is to account for slightly larger fluid dynamic density of the bulk catalyst and to ensure fluidization. Wherein, the fractions of particle in the desired range of 10–100 μm were 96.4% and 90.0% for fresh Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(IWI) and Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) catalysts, respectively. Both spent catalysts exhibit severely reduced particle diameters and a large increase in the fraction of fines in comparison with fresh samples. The mean particle size is reduced to 23.9 and 11.0 for the Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(IWI) and the Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) catalysts, respectively. Wherein, the fraction of fines (particles with the size < 10 μm) was increased up to 40.0 and 57.4% for supported and bulk catalysts, respectively. Except for a decrease in the particle size, there is a change in the form of its distribution which becomes bimodal and exhibits two local maxima at 10 and 50 µm in the case of Fe-K-Cu/Al2O3(IWI) catalyst. This change in the form of the distribution indicates that the main reason for size reduction is due to particle fracture (fragmentation mechanism). However, the wear of the catalyst could not be neglected. It is well known [75], that supported catalysts gain their mechanical resistance through their support, here Al2O3. Collisions with the harder stainless-steel impeller as well as imposed shear forces may cause such breakage. In the case of the Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC), the particle size distribution does not change shape but is shifted towards smaller particle sizes. As a bulk catalyst with more uniform material and shape distribution. We can say that main mechanism of the catalyst attrition is wear of the particle surface in the case of bulk Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) catalyst. Additionally, a decrease in particle size of the bulk catalyst could be caused by a change in chemical composition (FeOx→FeCx) during reduction and carbidization. For a time on stream of around 600 h, fine generation should be below 3% for slurry bubble column reactor operation [38]. While it is less pronounced for supported than bulk catalyst, both values at > 40% are too large to allow for commercial operation of these catalysts. It has to be noted that the mechanical stress on catalyst particles in a stirred tank exceed the one in a SBCR. To gain further insights into the excess-attrition caused by stirring, a similar experiment should be performed with an industrially employed catalyst to generate a benchmark. Thus, although the obtained Fe-Al-K-Cu(OC) catalyst prepared by the organic combustion has promising activity and selectivity, it does not have sufficient mechanical resistance to attrition. This indicates the challenge in the development of the CO2-FT catalysts of combining high mechanical strength to attrition and breakage during operating in slurry reactors with excellent catalytic performance. Because the obtained catalyst demonstrated the perspective potential in CO2 hydrogenation, further work will be devoted to increasing its attrition resistance by optimizing the granulation process of the powder of the suggested catalyst via different formation techniques (for example, spray drying [74]). 5 Conclusions This study presented a screening approach for finding highly selective CO2 hydrogenation catalysts for hydrocarbon production building upon the results of an earlier published literature data analysis of CO2-FT catalysts. Among the various preparation methods evaluated, the organic combustion method was the most effective for preparing highly selective and active CO2 hydrogenation catalysts, with a chain growth probability α of around 0.7. Further optimization of catalyst composition and reduction temperature yielded catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation as active and selective as the best ones reported in literature. The obtained catalysts satisfy not only high activity and selectivity but also technical requirements (necessary particle size and fluid dynamic density). Chain growth probability for the supported catalysts was found to be in a range of 0.42–0.54 which is clearly below the alpha-values for the bulk catalysts which was in the range 0.64–0.71. The lower alpha in supported catalysts seems to be related to the smaller particle size of the active component. The bulk catalysts show larger particle sizes and higher chain growth probability. Testing of the obtained catalysts in slurry reactor demonstrated that the most perspective catalyst has good performance (CO2 conversion 25%, CH4 selectivity 8%, C5+ selectivity around 50% the chain growth probability 0.7) at the following reaction conditions (250 °C, 25 bar, GHSV = 1800 cm³·g−1·h−1) that is comparable with the literature results for CO2 hydrogenation in slurry reactors. Promisingly high contents of oxygenates were found that could increase the overall product value. The investigation of the particle size of the spent catalysts after testing in the slurry reactor revealed that the obtained catalysts lack attrition resistance for technical application to be addressed in further catalyst development. The primary cause for attrition is still uncertain and needs to be investigated in future work. The fundamental knowledge regarding the correlation between the chain growth probability α and particle size of the active component as well as the demonstrated strategy may be useful in preparing and screening of new catalytic systems for CO2 hydrogenation with high selectivity to higher hydrocarbons. Exploring solutions for improving the mechanical strength of these promising catalysts is the next step before examining stability (both activity and attrition resistance) in a 3-phase bubble column reactor. coredata.dc:description: The development of CO2 hydrogenation catalysts for hydrocarbon production is a challenging and relevant task as it can contribute to solving of the CO2 emission problem. In the present work, we describe our journey in the development of catalysts for operating in a slurry reactor. The screening of the preparation methods and catalyst composition yielded an active and highly selective CO2 hydrogenation catalyst with catalytic performances comparable to the best ones reported in the literature. The most perspective catalysts were successfully evaluated in CO2 hydrogenation using a slurry reactor. The supported catalysts were found to have a lower ability to form higher hydrocarbons compared to bulk catalysts. This could be correlated with the particle sizes of the active component of the respective catalysts. This insight may be useful in preparing tailor-made Fe-based catalysts with high chain growth probability. The important issue of mechanical strength for slurry operation was highlighted.
coredata.dc:title: Development of Fe-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to higher hydrocarbons for operating in slurry reactor
